headline.main: Supreme Court Rules Against Retirees in Union Health Benefits Case
headline.print_headline: Supreme Court Rules Against Retirees in Union Health Benefits Case

docs.abstract: Supreme Court rules chemical company M&G Polymers USA can cut health benefits of its retired union employees, reversing appeals court judgement.
docs.snippet: The unanimous decision reversed a lower-court ruling that found the benefits had vested for life.

docs.lead_paragraph: Representatives of the United Steelworkers union (USW) and oil companies have completed six days of talks as of Monday for a new national contract that will cover hourly workers at 63 U.S. refineries that account for 64 percent of national refining capacity.

docs.lead_paragraph: Obamacare will cost 7 percent less than expected over the next decade for federal subsidies to help lower-income people pay for private health insurance, congressional researchers said on Monday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Solid economic growth will help the federal budget deficit shrink this year to its lowest level since President Barack Obama took office, according to congressional estimates released Monday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Medicare will change the way it pays hospitals and doctors to reward quality over volume, the Obama administration said Monday, in a shift that officials hope will be a catalyst for the nation's $3 trillion health care system.

docs.lead_paragraph: Tieless and eschewing the traditional religious swearing-in ceremony, but with a surprise coalition deal in the bag and a sanguine international reception, radical left leader Alexis Tsipras took over Monday as austerity-wracked Greece's new prime minister.
